Democracy.description: A system of government by the whole population, typically through elected representatives.

Oligarchy.description: A small group of people having control of a country or organization.

Absolute Monarchy.description: A form of governance where the monarch has almost complete control over the government and its subjects. The monarch's power is unchecked by any other institution, and they often have the final say in both domestic and foreign policies.

Constitutional Monarchy.description: A monarchy in which the monarch's powers are defined and limited by a constitution. This form of government blends monarchic elements with principles of democracy and rule of law, often resulting in the monarch having largely ceremonial duties.

Primogeniture.description: A system of inheritance or succession where the eldest child, traditionally the eldest son, inherits the throne, estate, or title. Primogeniture has been a common practice in monarchies and aristocracies, ensuring a clear and stable line of succession.

Dictatorship.description: Dictatorship is a form of government characterized by the concentration of power in the hands of a single individual or a ruling body, which exercises absolute authority over the state without the consent or competition of political rivals. This authoritarian regime type eschews democratic processes such as fair and free elections, civil liberties, and political pluralism, often justifying its rule on the basis of efficiency, national unity, or emergency conditions that purportedly require centralized control.

Anarchy.description: Anarchy, as a philosophical and political concept, is characterized by the absence of centralized government and the presence of a stateless society where individuals and communities self-organize and self-govern without hierarchical authority. Anarchism, the ideology advocating for anarchy, envisions a society based on voluntary cooperation, mutual aid, and the freedom of individuals to live their lives without imposed rulers or oppressive structures. It posits that, in the absence of coercive governance, people can create more equitable, just, and harmonious social relations.

Theocracy.description: Theocracy is a form of government in which a deity is recognized as the supreme civil ruler, with the deity's laws being interpreted by ecclesiastical authorities. In practice, it means that religious leaders govern the state, and the state's legal system is based upon religious law. Theocratic governance integrates religious doctrine with political governance, blurring the lines between secular and sacred institutions.

Technocracy.description: The government or control of society or industry by an elite of technical experts.

Meritocracy.description: Government or the holding of power by people selected on the basis of their ability.

Feudal System.description: The social system in medieval Europe, in which the nobility held lands from the Crown in exchange for military service.

Empire.description: An extensive group of states or countries ruled over by a single monarch, an oligarchy, or a sovereign state.

Republic.description: A state in which supreme power is held by the people and their elected representatives, and which has an elected or nominated president rather than a monarch.

Confederation.description: An organization that consists of a number of parties or groups united in an alliance or league. The Confederation is often established for mutual benefit and security.

Corporate State.description: A state in which corporations control government and politics openly. Democracy has been replaced with corporate enforcers and plentiful disctractions.

Tribalism.description: The state or fact of being organized in a tribe comprised of a number of families.

Matriarchy.description: A system of society or government ruled by a woman or women.

Patriarchy.description: A system of society or government in which men hold the power and women are largely excluded from it.

Cyberocracy.description: A form of government where decisions are algorithmic and the citizens democratically maintain the code underlying the public decision systems.

Eco-Governance.description: Governance principally by anf ro ecological principles to manage impact on the environment and maintain a stable homeostasis with the ecological system of the planet.

Direct Democracy.description: A form of democracy in which people decide on policy initiatives directly. Citizens vote on laws and engage in discourse in large public forums.

Plutocracy.description: Government run openly or secretly by the wealthy. This may include some form of oligarchy or corporatocracy with a facade of democracy to give the appearance of a representative government.

Syndicalist Union.description: A government run for and by the worker class. The workers own and manage the means of production and the government is run by workers councils.

State Communism.description: A society in which all property is publicly owned and each person works and is paid according to their abilities and needs. Under this system, the centralized state is the sole owner of all property and the means of production.

Participatory Democracy.description: Representative democracy with an emphasis on the broad participation of constituents in the direction and operation of political systems. A form of e-democracy with representatives.

Gerontocracy.description: Government by the elderly. A form of oligarchy where the oldest members of society hold the most power.

Stratocracy.description: Government by the military. A form of oligarchy where the military holds the most power. The government structure is such that military officials are the ruling class, and political power is derived from military authority and service. Citizenship rights, including voting and civil participation, are linked to military service.

Timocracy.description: Political power is vested in individuals who possess a certain amount of property and who are considered to have merit or honor. This system values martial virtues and the spirit of the warrior class, reflecting a society that prioritizes honor, military service, and the possession of land or wealth as qualifications for political leadership and influence.

Nomocracy.description: n a nomocracy, the principle of the rule of law stands paramount, implying that every individual, institution, and entity, public or private, including the state itself, is accountable to laws that are publicly promulgated, equally enforced, and independently adjudicated, and which are consistent with international human rights principles. Laws and rights are established through legislation, and the power of the state is limited by law.

Kratocracy.description: Government by those who are strong enough to seize power through force or cunning. A form of oligarchy where the strongest hold the most power. Rights are often determined by the strength of the individual.

Ochlocracy.description: Mob rule, government by mob or a mass of people. A form of democracy where the mob holds the most power, leading to rule by mass sentiment and impulse rather than by laws and legitimate governing structures. Often leads to tyranny.

Kritarchy.description: n a kritarchy, judges may have the authority to legislate, execute, and interpret laws, leading to a significant concentration of power. This can result in a unique form of governance that may prioritize legal principles and judicial processes in the administration of the state.

Panarchism.description: In a panarchistic system, the traditional concept of a monolithic state governing all aspects of life within a defined territorial boundary is replaced by overlapping jurisdictions and a multiplicity of governance structures. People could, in theory, be part of a socialist system, participate in a free-market capitalist system, live under a theocracy, or engage in any other governance structure of their choice, all within the same geographic area. This requires a polycentric legal system to manage the interactions between the different governance structures as well as complex production and distribution systems to manage the different economic systems.

Sortition.description: Sortition, also known as allotment or demarchy, is a method of selecting officeholders or decision-makers in a government or organization through a random process, akin to drawing lots. This approach stands in contrast to electoral systems where officeholders are chosen through voting.

Band Society.description: The simplest form of human society, characterized by a lack of hierarchical leadership. Bands have a small population, are nomadic, and they are often organized around kinship ties and are egalitarian.

Chiefdom.description: Political organization with a chief at the head. Chiefdoms are characterized by a centralized authority, a large population, and a complex social hierarchy. They are often organized around kinship ties and are less egalitarian than bands.

Mutual Aid Society.description: System where groups of individuals work together for common or mutually beneficial goals. Anarchist mechanisms are used to determine organization and structure of the society while mutual aid networks fill any gaps.

Consociationalism.description: Consociationalism is a form of government designed to regulate and manage societal division by ensuring that major ethnic, religious, linguistic, or cultural groups have a degree of autonomous governance and representation in the political process. This approach is particularly applied in pluralistic societies marked by deep-seated divisions, with the aim of promoting stability, democracy, and the protection of minority rights through power-sharing mechanisms.

Digital Democracy.description: Refers to a form of government where information technology and digital communication tools are used extensively to facilitate democratic processes. This model leverages the online deliberation, proxy voting, cryptographic computing, and other digital systems to enhance citizen engagement, transparency, and participation in the political process.

Egalitarian Tribe.description: An early form of society or government based on the principle of equality. Egalitarian tribes are characterized by a lack of hierarchy, with decisions made through consensus and an emphasis on sharing and cooperation.

State Capitalism.description: A political system in which the state has control of production and the use of capital. The state directs the economy and controls the means of production, but the market system is used for the distribution of goods and services.

Market Socialism.description: An economic system in which there is a market economy directed and regulated by the state but operated by cooperatives.

Libertarian Socialism.description: A political philosophy that advocates for the abolition of the state and the establishment of a society based on voluntary associations and cooperative ownership of the means of production.

Anarcho-Syndicalist Union.description: A theory of anarchism that views revolutionary industrial unionism or syndicalism as the method for workers in capitalist society to gain control of an economy.

Anarcho-Communism.description: A theory of anarchism which advocates the abolition of the state, private property, and capitalism in favor of common ownership of the means of production.

Council Communism.description: A form of communism led by workers councils as opposed to a party-led state.

Anarcho-Primitivism.description: A modern society that has abandoned technology and complex social structures in favor of a simple, hunter-gatherer lifestyle. Anarcho-primitivists believe that civilization is inherently harmful and advocate for a return to a pre-agricultural way of life.

Communalism.description: A political system where local councils form the basis of governance, operating on principles of direct democracy, from the bottom up, often emphasizing ecological and communal living. Collective ownership of resources through economic cooperatives allows workers to manage their own production and distribution.
